body.p:
You are no doubt by
this time in possession of the second letter from our
mutual friend, Mr. G. Kursheedt. In it you were
advised, that I would write to you in the course of
2 or 3 days. I redeem this promise and would merely
add, that I would ere this have written to you on the
subject in question, had not Mr. K. anticipated me.
Mr. K. has acted very promptly in this matter and has,
as far as circumstances would permit him, evinced
a truly friendly and sincere regard for your claims.
His second letter was written in my presence. You
may rely on its statements. They are no crude sup
positions, no hasty, inconsiderate conclusions, but
the result of an impartial, unbiased examination
of the queries, which you propounded. Mr. K. thought
it his duty (and I fully agreed with him) to let you
know the true state of things—frankly, openly, un-
equivocably. You may, therefore safely base your course
of action with regard to NO. ministery, on the
statements contained in that letter.

I have no new light
to throw on the subject. But a good deal might
be said, whether or not you should continue to
hold

hold back from active service. May I presume to in-
dulge some friendly advice, similar to that which
you reprovingly admiministered to me some years
ago, when I was about withdrawing from the ministry?
It is true, you have not altogether withdrawn from the
legitimate labors of your vacation. You are en-
gaged in literary undertakings, which will prove
of great benefit to our people. But in my humble
judgement, these need not be abandoned, tho' their ex-
ecution might be attended with some difficulty, were
you to accept office in this city. I would therefore
say, weigh the matter well, before you come to a
final determination; and altho' the terms, under which
the office is offered to you, may at first sight app-
ear humiliating to your pride in a worldly point
of view, yet I cannot conceive, how it can affect
your well established character. The reduction of
salary only tends to show the straitened means of
the congregation, but cannot in any shape or manner
be tortured to argue the inferiority of the successor
to the present incumbent. The very attempt to do so
would be ridiculous. Any one might with the same
propriety contend, that I am totally unfit for the
office, because I receive less than half the sal-
ary of my worthy colleague. Were the Salary
therefore the only consideration, you have no right
to decline. Regarding, however, the prospect of

election and term of office I can say but little.
In this respect you must be guided by your own
feelings. Nothing, however, I assume you would give
me greater pleasure than to see you again at the
head of a respectable congregation, and more part-
icularly in my immediate neighborhood.

I am greatly indebted to you
for the prompt manner, in which you came forth
in defence of my name in the Occident. I dont
think, however, that Mr. Mack did not mean to
depreciate my character. He is an inexperienced
writer and no doubt hits upon the words for the
rounding of the sentence. You must know, that
Mr Mack was one of my staunchest supporters
who would have made a pretty little sacrifice, could
he have secured my reelection in Cincinnati.
And well he might. No one knows better than Mr
M. thro' what labor I have gone in behalf of his synagogue and congregation, how strenuous and per-
severing were my exertions in promoting its welfare
and establishing its character for the paltry sum
of $500 p. a. he is the last of all men, whom
I could have thought capable of casting a reflect
ion on my efficiency. The very school, of which he
boasts so much, was called into life chiefly
thro' my cooperation. And I had intended to send
you a sermon, which I delivered 4 years ago

in Cincinnati and in which I expressed my views
on the apathy of our people in pretty strong language
This sermon is written in German and was
thought so pertinent to the subject school-project, that Mr
Mack asked it of me and had it circulated
among his friends for digestion. But I would
not take the trouble to translate it, nor tax
you with it. I thought it indelicate on my
part, to give the subject the slightest notice
I thought, however, God save me of my friends
all.

I am just in receipt of a letter from
Mr. De Sola, Montreal, advising me of his
intention of publishing Beth? English's
work, for circulation among the Jews
only. The work is out of print, and its
republication can only be of benefit.

May God guide your counsels, and
bless you with long life and happiness.
